article.title: Genomic analysis reveals the presence of emerging pathogenic Klebsiella lineages aboard the International Space Station
article.abstract: Klebsiella species, such as Klebsiella pneumoniae, Klebsiella aerogenes, and Klebsiella quasipneumoniae, are opportunistic pathogens that commonly cause infections in humans.

sections.introduction: The genus Klebsiella includes eight species of facultative anaerobic Gram-negative bacteria ubiquitously found in natural environments (1). They can also be found as human and animal gastrointestinal commensals.
sections.methods: Various locations were sampled on the ISS using polyester wipes, and the metadata associated with the samples and their collections were published elsewhere (43).
sections.results: As expected, the Klebsiella isolates (n=10) exhibited resistance to ampicillin and rifampicin.
sections.discussion: This study highlights the presence of Klebsiella isolates associated with human pathogenic lineages.

article.insights_summary: This study highlights the presence of Klebsiella isolates associated with human pathogenic lineages aboard the International Space Station.
article.acknowledgments: We would like to thank Aleksandra Checinska-Sielaff for isolating the strains.
